Title: Wrap It Up: Deciphering experience-dependent myelin growth across development

The WRAPPED project aims to elucidate the biological basis of the unique human learning trajectory by assessing changes in myelin during learning at different developmental stages. Using an innovative two-pronged approach that combines local longitudinal studies with the analysis of large-scale open data, we will probe the entire developmental lifespan to understand how myelin levels in the living human brain change over time and between individuals. Our study will focus on critical periods of learning, including when infants learn to crawl, children enter school, and young adults and older adults acquire novel skills such as juggling and reading Chinese.

By establishing a vital reference point for understanding psychological and neurological disorders linked to alterations in myelin, our project will shed light on the underlying mechanisms of disorders such as schizophrenia, autism, and childhood learning disabilities. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) will be employed to non-invasively measure myelin growth in the brain.

The WRAPPED project has two primary objectives: (1) to elucidate the biological basis of the unique human learning trajectory, and (2) to establish a vital reference point for understanding psychological and neurological disorders linked to alterations in myelin. By achieving these objectives, our project will provide a foundational understanding of experience-dependent myelin growth and its impact on human development and disease.
